hawaiian_text: A hala ‘o Puali‘i i ka lawai‘a, i ia wā ‘o   Nāmakaokapāo‘o i hele ai me nā keiki he ‘umi  kumamāhiku i nā māla ‘uala a Puali‘i. ‘O ke kino o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ia wā, he kino ‘u‘uku loa, ‘elua  kapua‘i me ka hapa kona ki‘eki‘e, ‘a‘ole i pa‘a kona  ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō. A hiki lākou i ua māla  ‘uala, kēnā akula ia i nā keiki, “E huhuki i ka pu‘e  me ka lau ‘uala ā pau loa i luna, mai waiho i kekahi e ulu ana.” Akā, maka‘u nō ua keiki, no laila, kāohi  mālie nō ma ka ‘uala, ‘a‘ohe huhuki i ka pu‘e.
gpt-4_1-mini_translation: Puali‘i went fishing, while at that time Nāmakaokapāo‘o went with seventeen children to Puali‘i’s sweet potato patches. Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s body at that time was very small, two kapua‘i and a half of his height, not yet fully developed, still immature. When they arrived at the sweet potato patches, he said to the children, “Pull up the mounds along with all the sweet potato leaves on top, don’t leave any growing.” But the children were afraid, so they carefully controlled themselves with the sweet potatoes, not pulling up the mounds.
gpt-4_1-mini_commentary:
**Paragraph 5:**  
• This paragraph situates Nāmakaokapāo‘o within a group of seventeen children working together in the agricultural setting of Puali‘i’s sweet potato (ʻuala) patches. The coordination of many children (he ʻumi kumamāhiku) highlights communal labor, an important aspect of traditional Hawaiian farming practices where mo‘opuna or keiki were often involved under adult supervision.  
• The presence of seventeen children is significant: seventeen (ʻumi kumamāhiku) is a relatively large number, possibly symbolic of community strength or collective responsibility. It may also be a semi-symbolic “many” rather than a literal headcount. Hawaiian oral narratives often use numbers to convey magnitude and emphasize social dynamics.

• Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s physical description is both precise and poetic:  
  – “Two kapua‘i and a half his height” places him as very small and childlike. The *kapua‘i* is a traditional Hawaiian unit of measure approximately the length of a clenched fist or about four inches (10 cm), though it can vary regionally. Two and a half kapua‘i indicates a stature roughly 10 inches tall—emphasizing his youth and vulnerability.  
  – His description as “not fully mature” or “not yet fully formed” (ʻaʻole i pa‘a kona ma‘i, e lewalewa ana nō) conveys both a literal physical immaturity and perhaps a symbolic psychological or emotional immaturity. The term *ma‘i*, commonly meaning disease or illness, here likely refers figuratively to an undeveloped or weak condition.  
  – The juxtaposition of his diminutive size with the leadership role of giving instructions to the other children may indicate narrative tension between apparent weakness and emerging strength or responsibility—common in hero narratives. 

• The agricultural task itself reflects traditional Hawaiian sweet potato cultivation practices:  
  – The instruction “pull up the mounds along with all the sweet potato leaves on top, don’t leave any growing” suggests complete harvesting and clearing. In Hawaiian agriculture, *pu‘e* refers to a planting mound, which is cultivated carefully for *uala* tubers. Removing leaves and vines entirely helps stop regrowth, indicating a planned harvest cycle.  
  – The directive to “not leave any growing” also has potential metaphoric significance. It can symbolize transformation or clearing away old growth to make way for the new, consistent with themes of renewal in Hawaiian land stewardship (*malama ‘aina*).  
  – The children’s fear (maka‘u nō) to fully pull up the mounds suggests a hesitation to disrupt or destroy the life-giving plants—a cultural respect for the land (*aina*) and its sustaining power, but also imperative caution among keiki. This ambivalence aligns with Hawaiian concepts of reciprocity between humans and nature, where harvesting is done mindfully and respectfully.

• The contrast between Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s firm command and the children’s hesitation adds narrative depth:  
  – It may highlight his emerging assertiveness or a symbolic rupture with traditional cautiousness—he encourages decisive action, perhaps foreshadowing a disruptive role in the story.  
  – This aligns with the characterization seen in prior paragraphs, where Nāmakaokapāo‘o is both a child and a figure involved in challenging existing norms or provoking change. His youth and physical smallness contrast with his emerging agency.

• Cultural and narrative context:  
  – The presence of Puali‘i as a separate fishing character (although not directly interacting in this paragraph) sets up a duality between land (uala patches) and sea (fishing). This dichotomy is common in Hawaiian stories, symbolizing different realms of resource gathering and modes of life.  
  – The agricultural setting and child labor suggest a period either before or around the end of the ‘Ai Kapu era (pre-1819), when strict kapu governed social behavior including agricultural cycles and fishing rights. The caution shown by the children may be a remnant of ritual observance or fear of spiritual consequences, while Nāmakaokapāo‘o’s directive may symbolize the beginning of a new approach or defiance.

• Onomastic note:  
  – *Nāmakaokapāo‘o* (the eyes of the pāo‘o fish) bears poetic and symbolic weight. The pāo‘o is a fish associated with sharp vision and keen observation; his name may metaphysically link him to perception and insight, despite his physical smallness and immaturity here.  
  – The imagery of “eyes” dovetails with themes of seeing beyond present limitations and potentially challenging established orders, consistent with his assertive actions as a youth among the children.

In summary, this paragraph portrays Nāmakaokapāo‘o as a physically small but increasingly assertive figure commanding a group of children to undertake an important agricultural task. The tension between his confident instructions and the children’s cautious restraint reflects cultural values of respect for land and possibly an allegory for forthcoming changes in tradition or social order. The detailed physical description anchors the character in the narrative as a youthful yet pivotal actor with symbolic potential tied to insight and transformation.

reference_translation: When Puali‘i left to go fishing, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  came with seventeen other children to the sweet  potato patches of Puali‘i. The body of   Nāmakaokapāo‘o at the time was very small, just  two and a half feet tall. His penis was not yet fully  grown and was dangling. When the kids got to the   sweet potato patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o told the  other kids, “Rip out all of the sweet potato leaves. Don’t leave anything growing.” The children were  afraid and hesitated when they reached the  tubers, and they did not pull those out of the  mound.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 5:**• While Pua-li‘i was away fishing, Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  came with 17 other children (perhaps all boys) to the  2 sweet potato patches. The reason they came to the  patches is not stated immediately, but it appears the  reason was to play. The 17 friends of Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o seem to represent the Hawaiian people as a  whole (or perhaps a group of individuals the  storyteller thinks poorly of) allegorically and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o seems to represent a progressive minded Hawaiian.  • Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o is described at this point of the  story as very small, perhaps 2 feet tall, and that his  penis was not yet fully grown and dangling, likely  meaning he was not wearing a malo.  – The lack of a malo on a boy is descriptive of the  child being too young to wear one. In ‘Ai Kapu  culture, when boys are deemed to be physically  able for chores and work to help sustain the family,  they would go through rites to thrust them into an  age of productive work to help support the family  demonstrated by wearing a malo on a daily basis. It  was a sign of maturity (footnote: Pukui, Haertig, Lee (1972:114) “For the *keiki lewalewa*—usually shortened to *lewalewa*—was yet a “dangler.” A small boy, so young his penis dangled. As a dangler, he wore no  *malo* (loincloth) and he lived and ate with the women. For he was yet *poke‘o*, too young to join the men. ¶ When the little dangler became six or seven years old, his status  changed in one decisive ceremony. This was the *kā i mua*...”);  • The description of Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o as a pre malo-wearing child contradicts the maturity and  leadership he demonstrates by his actions and  cognitive skills, where he tells his friends to destroy  the garden. The children demonstrate hesitancy and  destroy the vines and leaves of the sweet potatoes,  but do not dig out the tubers from under the ground. – This likely demonstrates a social rhetorical   commentary about or critique of the ‘Ai Kapu  culture as a whole, that it was worthy of   destruction, with its segregation of men and  women and emphasis on heirarchy, perhaps a  justification for abandoning the culture in 1819\.  The hesitancy of the children, and their depiction in this story as indecisive and timid could be a   Protestant Christian bias (post-1820). The idea of  not pulling out the sweet potato tubers from the  ground could represent not entirely eliminating the  Hawaiian people/culture in the Christian era (not a  complete genocide) despite the biases against the  ‘Ai Kapu;
